question: How do privacy technologies balance security needs with civil liberties?

expert_sources.title: Apple vs FBI San Bernardino Case

key_findings.finding: End-to-end encryption prevents any third party, including providers, from reading messages
Cryptographic backdoors would weaken security for everyone, not just targets
Zero-knowledge proofs enable verification without revealing underlying data
Law enforcement argues encryption enables criminals; privacy advocates cite civil liberties
Different democracies take different positions (EU emphasizes privacy, Five Eyes push access)
Client-side scanning proposals attempt compromise but face technical and privacy concerns

known_counterarguments.argument: Strong encryption makes legitimate investigations impossible
known_counterarguments.validity: Partially valid, but metadata and other evidence often available

known_counterarguments.argument: Privacy is not absolute and must yield to safety
known_counterarguments.validity: Value judgment, but technical tradeoffs matter

known_counterarguments.argument: Technical solutions can provide lawful access without weakening security

areas_of_uncertainty: Future technical solutions that don't exist yet

must_include: Law enforcement vs civil liberties tension
At least one technical approach (ZKP or similar)
